perturbation.original_text:
2.5               Sponsor's Fee

For the  services  of the  Sponsor as sponsor  of the  Offering  and as full and complete  compensation  therefor,  the Issuer will pay to the Sponsor the sum of $32,100  (inclusive  of  Goods  and  Services  Tax),  the  receipt  of  which is acknowledged by the Sponsor.
perturbation.changed_text:
2.5               Sponsor's Fee

For the  services  of the  Sponsor as sponsor  of the  Offering  and as full and complete  compensation  therefor,  the Issuer will pay to the Sponsor a fee as agreed upon in a separate side agreement. The details of the fee structure are outlined in that agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the explicit fee amount ($32,100) and referencing a separate side agreement, the contract now relies on an external document for a key term. If that side agreement does not exist or is not properly executed, it creates uncertainty in enforcement regarding the Sponsor's compensation. It creates an internal contradiction if Section 7, 'COSTS, EXPENSES AND TAXES' still refers to expenses related to the original understanding of the fee.

perturbation.original_text:
5.                EXPERT OPINIONS

The Issuer shall deliver to the Sponsor on the date of filing the Prospectus:

                  (a)      a  letter  dated  as of a  date  not  more  than  one                            Business Day prior to the date of the Prospectus,  in                            form and substance  satisfactory to the Sponsor, from                            the then current auditor of the Issuer:

                           (i)      stating that, in such auditor's opinion, the                                     financial  statements  and notes  thereto of                                     the Issuer  examined by them and included in                                     the Prospectus covered by his report therein                                     comply as to form in all  material  respects                                     with the applicable accounting  requirements                                     of the Securities Law; and

                           (ii)     stating that, in such auditor's opinion, the                                     balance sheet of the Issuer  examined by the                                     auditor and included in the  Prospectus  and                                     covered by his report therein complies as to                                     form  in  all  material  respects  with  the                                     applicable  accounting  requirements  of the                                     Securities Law; and

                           (iii)    addressing  such other  matters  relating to                                     the financial  information in the Prospectus                                     to which the Sponsor may reasonably  require                                     comfort;

                  (b)      a  favourable  legal  opinion,  in form  and  content                            reasonably satisfactory to the Sponsor, by counsel to                            the  Issuer  dated  the  date of the  Prospectus  and                            addressed  to the  Sponsor,  relating  to such  legal                            matters  as  the  Sponsor  may  reasonably   request,                            including, without limitation, certain of the matters                            in section 3.1, title to the Issuer's  property,  and                            matters pertaining to the Securities Law;

                  (c)      a certificate of the Issuer certifying  certain facts                            relating  to the  business  of the  Issuer,  and  its                            affairs  as  may  be  reasonably   requested  by  the                            Sponsor; and

                  (d)      any other  certificates,  comfort letters or opinions                            in  connection   with  any  matter   related  to  the                            Prospectus  which  are  reasonably  requested  by the                            Sponsor or their legal counsel.
perturbation.changed_text:
5.                EXPERT OPINIONS

The Issuer shall deliver to the Sponsor all expert opinions required by regulatory bodies.

                  (a)      The form and substance of these opinions will conform to the standards of the relevant field.

                  (b)     Counsel to the issuer will provide legal opinions deemed necessary.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the detailed requirements for the expert opinions and replacing them with vague statements about regulatory requirements and 'deemed necessary' legal opinions, the contract becomes much less specific. This introduces uncertainty about what constitutes compliance. If Section 6.2 (f), referencing conditions in Section 5, remains, it creates a contradiction: the Sponsor could terminate the agreement if the vague requirements are not 'satisfied,' but the vagueness makes it unclear what 'satisfaction' entails. It also contradicts section 3.1(e) about the prospectus if expert opinions are needed to validate its information.

perturbation.original_text:
3.3               Survival of Representations and Warranties

Each of the parties  hereto  acknowledges  that the other parties are relying on each of the representations  and warranties  addressed to such other parties set forth in section 3.1 or 3.2, as the case may be, and any representations made in any  certificate  issued to such other parties in connection with this Agreement notwithstanding  any  investigations  heretofore or hereafter made by such other parties  or their  counsel  or  representatives.  All such  representations  and warranties  shall not merge in or be  prejudiced  by,  and shall  survive  for a period of three years from the completion of the distribution of the Units.
perturbation.changed_text:
3.3               Survival of Representations and Warranties

Each of the parties  hereto  acknowledges  that the other parties are relying on each of the representations  and warranties. The representations and warranties will be valid until the closure of the distribution of the Units.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states that representations and warranties survive for three years after distribution. The modified version removes this specific duration and states the representations and warranties will only be valid until closure. This introduces uncertainty and a contradiction if other sections of the agreement, like the indemnification clause (Section 8), implicitly assume a longer period for liability. For example, if a misrepresentation is discovered two years after distribution, it is unclear if the original indemnification still applies because the representations and warranties have ostensibly expired.
